titleText.ttltext: Factors involved in human papillomavirus (HPV) @hit_startvaccine@hit_end hesitancy among women in the South-East Asian Region (SEAR) and Western Pacific Region (WPR): A scoping review

paras: A scoping review was performed to identify factors that may lead to human papillomavirus (HPV) @hit_startvaccine@hit_end hesitancy among women in low- and middle-income countries in South East Asian Region (SEAR) and Western Pacific Region (WPR). A systematic search of English and non-English articles using @hit_startPubmed@hit_end, @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end, @hit_startPsycINFO@hit_end, @hit_startCochrane@hit_end, @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, and @hit_startCINAHL@hit_end plus was conducted. Only 63 studies conducted in SEAR and WPR were included from inception until December 2016. Results of these studies have shown that poor awareness and knowledge of practices on cervical cancer prevention was evident in both SEAR and WPR. Concerns on safety and efficacy of the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, and costs in getting @hit_startvaccinated@hit_end were significant barriers. Most women stated that they needed more information, and strongly welcomed a physician's recommendation in both geographical regions. Women also felt they have a low risk of acquiring HPV infection and cervical cancer. Most women in SEAR and WPR were unable to decide on whether to accept HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end.

titleText.ttltext: Enhanced @hit_startimmunization@hit_end techniques to obtain highly specific monoclonal antibodies

organizations: Univ Estadual Paulista - UNESP, School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Department of Bioprocess and Biotechnology

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018 The Author(s). Published with license by Taylor & Francis Group, LLC © 2018, © Rodrigo de Almeida, Cecília Naomi Nakamura, Marina de Lima Fontes, Elenice Deffune, Sérgio Luis Felisbino, Ramon Kaneno, Wagner José Fávaro, Athanase Billis, Marcel Otavio Cerri, Ana Marisa Fusco-Almeida, Maria José Mendes Giannini, Andrei Moroz.
paras: Despite fast advances in genomics and proteomics, monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) are still a valuable tool for areas such as the evolution of basic research in stem cells and cancer, for immunophenotyping cell populations, diagnosing and prognosis of diseases, and for immunotherapy. To summarize different subtractive @hit_startimmunization@hit_end approaches successfully used for the production of highly specific antibodies, we identified scientific articles in NCBI @hit_startPubMed@hit_end using the following search terms: subtractive @hit_startimmunization@hit_end, monoclonal antibody, tolerization, neonatal, high-zone tolerance, masking @hit_startimmunization@hit_end. Patent records were also consulted. From the list of results, we included all available reports, from 1985 to present, that used any enhanced @hit_startimmunization@hit_end technique to produce either polyclonal or monoclonal antibodies. Our examination yielded direct evidence that these enhanced @hit_startimmunization@hit_end techniques are efficient in obtaining specific antibodies to rare epitopes, with different applications, such as to identify food contaminants or tumor cells.

titleText.ttltext: The case for vitamin D supplementation to improve protection against respiratory tract infections

paras: Background: An adequate vitamin D status is essential for normal immune function. Vitamin D sub-nutrition is widespread, especially in low sunlight regions and in certain high-risk groups. There is growing evidence that vitamin D supplementation can reduce the risk of infection of the respiratory tract. Objective: The aim was to review the mechanisms whereby vitamin D supports the chemistry of optimal innate and adaptive @hit_startimmunity@hit_end, and to evaluate critically the current evidence for the use of vitamin D supplements to help to minimize respiratory infection risk, particularly in individuals with sub-optimal vitamin D plasma levels. Method: @hit_startPUBMED@hit_end and @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end were searched using the terms: vitamin D; cholecalciferol; calcitriol; calcifediol; respiratory infections; influenza; pneumonia; respiratory syncytial virus, respiratory tract infection; chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD); @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end; @hit_startvaccination@hit_end; innate @hit_startimmunity@hit_end; adaptive @hit_startimmunity@hit_end. Papers for citation were selected by the authors on the basis of quality and relevance. Findings: Vitamin D is needed for optimal function of innate and adaptive immune systems. The evidence for a protective effect of vitamin supplementation is the strongest for viral infection, particularly in people with plasma calcifediol levels below 25 nmol/L. However, the role of vitamin D in influenza risk and as an adjunct to influenza @hit_startimmunization@hit_end is not clear. There is some evidence that a sufficient vitamin D status reduces the risk of infective exacerbations of COPD, and probably helps in the defence against some bacterial infections of the respiratory tract. Conclusion: Individuals with vitamin D deficiency have enhanced protection against some respiratory infections when given supplements. There are also other benefits including improved bone and muscle function, and mood. Further research is needed to identify sub-groups most likely to benefit from supplements.

titleText.ttltext: Interventions to increase referral and uptake to pulmonary rehabilitation in people with COPD: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end

organizations: Centre for Self-Management Support, Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust
affiliation.addressPart: Box 146, Cambridge Biomedical Campus, Hills Road

paras: Pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) reduces the number and duration of hospital admissions and readmissions, and improves health-related quality of life in patients with COPD. Despite clinical guideline recommendations, under-referral and limited uptake to PR contribute to poor treatment access. We @hit_startreviewed@hit_end published @hit_startliterature@hit_end on the effectiveness of interventions to improve referral to and uptake of PR in patients with COPD when compared to standard care, alternative interventions, or no intervention. The review followed recognized methods. Search terms included “pulmonary rehabilitation” AND “referral” OR “uptake” applied to @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end, @hit_startCINAHL@hit_end, @hit_startPsycINFO@hit_end, ASSIA, BNI, Web of Science, and @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Library up to January 2018. Titles, abstracts, and full papers were reviewed independently and quality appraised. The protocol was registered (PROSPERO # 2016:CRD42016043762). We screened 5,328 references. Fourteen papers met the inclusion criteria. Ten assessed referral and five assessed uptake (46,146 patients, 409 clinicians, 82 hospital departments, 122 general practices). One was a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end which assessed uptake. Designs, interventions, and scope of studies were diverse, often part of multifaceted evidence-based management of COPD. Examples included computer-based prompts at practice nurse review, patient information, clinician education, and financial incentives. Four studies reported statistically significant improvements in referral (range 3.5%-36%). Two studies reported statistically significant increases in uptake (range 18%-21.5%). Most studies had methodological and reporting limitations. @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end was not conducted due to heterogeneity of study designs. This review demonstrates the range of approaches aimed at increasing referral and uptake to PR but identifies limited evidence of effectiveness due to the heterogeneity and limitations of study designs. Research using robust methods with clear descriptions of intervention, setting, and target population is required to optimize access to PR across a range of settings.

titleText.ttltext: HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end and autoimmune diseases: @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of the literature

organizations: Department of Biomedical Sciaences and Morphological and Functional Images, AOU Policlinico G. Martino,Torre Biologica, University of Messina

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018 Pacini Editore S.p.A. All Rights Reserved.
paras: Background. In the literature conflicting opinions are detectable on the onset of adverse events as autoimmune disease post HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end and often case reports describes the onset of one of these events, but don't emerge a clear relationship and we don't have data to support it. Methods. We carried out a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end to identify all scientific publications dealing with the correlation between @hit_startvaccine@hit_end anti-papillomavirus and new onset of autoimmune diseases. We searched the main scientific databases (@hit_startPubMed@hit_end, Sciverse Scopus, Web of knowledge and @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Central Register of Controlled Clinical Trials) for the following search terms: "@hit_startvaccine@hit_end"; "anti-papillomavirus"; "autoimmune"; "disease"; "disorder". To evaluate the safety of HPV @hit_startvaccines@hit_end, the dichotomous data on the number of subjects experiencing an autoimmune disorder in the study @hit_startvaccine@hit_end group and the placebo group were extracted from each study with subsequent determination of the risk ratios and their 95% confidence intervals. We combined data statistically using a random effects model. Results. We conduct a @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end on six studies on bivalent and quadrivalent HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end. The total number of subjects included in the @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end comprised 243,289 in the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end group and 248,820 in control groups. Four of the six trials had a Jadad score of 3 or 4 indicating an adequate trial quality. The most frequent autoimmune disease observed across the six studies were musculoskeletal,CNS conditions and endocrinological conditions . The results of the @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end demonstrated no correlation between autoimmune disorders and HPV @hit_startvaccines@hit_end (pooled OR 1.038, 95% CI 0.689-1.562). Conclusions. No correlation was identified for bivalent and quadrivalent HPV @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. It's therefore essential to correctly inform the general population in order to try to increase both Italian and international @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage.

titleText.ttltext: The Urinary Tract Microbiome in Health and Disease

organizations: Department of Urology, Virgen de la Victoria University Hospital, Campus Universitario de Teatinos s/n

paras: Context: The urinary tract, previously considered a sterile body niche, has emerged as the host of an array of bacteria in healthy individuals, revolutionizing the urology research field. Objective: To @hit_startreview@hit_end the @hit_startliterature@hit_end on microbiome implications in the urinary tract and the usefulness of probiotics/prebiotics and diet as treatment for urologic disorders. Evidence acquisition: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end was conducted using @hit_startPubMed@hit_end and @hit_startMedline@hit_end from inception until July 2016. The initial search identified 1419 studies and 89 were included in this @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end. Evidence synthesis: Specific bacterial communities have been found in the healthy urinary tract. Changes in this microbiome have been observed in certain urologic disorders such as urinary incontinence, urologic cancers, interstitial cystitis, neurogenic bladder dysfunction, sexually transmitted infections, and chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome. The role of probiotics, prebiotics, and diet as treatment or preventive agents for urologic disorders requires further investigation. Conclusions: There is a microbiome associated with the healthy urinary tract that can change in urologic disorders. This represents a propitious context to identify new diagnostic, prognostic, and predictive microbiome-based biomarkers that could be used in clinical urology practice. In addition, probiotics, prebiotics, and diet modifications appear to represent an opportunity to regulate the urinary microbiome. Patient summary: We review the urinary microbiome of healthy individuals and its changes in relation to urinary disorders. The question to resolve is how we can modulate the microbiome to improve urinary tract health. The urinary tract has a specific microbiome that can change in urologic disorders. Changes in the specific urinary microbial communities point to the microbiome as a possible therapeutic target. How we can modulate the microbiome to improve urinary tract health remains a key question. Further investigations are required to provide new diagnostic, prognostic, and predictive microbiome-based biomarkers that could be used in clinical practice and translational research.

titleText.ttltext: Concordant testing results between various human papillomavirus assays in primary cervical cancer screening: @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end

organizations: Department of Pathology, Copenhagen University Hospital Hvidovre

paras: Objectives Human papillomavirus (HPV) assays are increasingly used for primary cervical screening and HPV-@hit_startvaccination@hit_end-effect monitoring. We undertook a @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end to determine the concordance in positive test results (i.e. detection of HPV infections) between Hybrid Capture 2 (HC2) and other assays. Methods We searched @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end and Scopus for studies of primary screening with HC2 and one or more assays, with cross-tabulated testing results for the assays. Two authors applied inclusion criteria and three authors extracted data from included studies. For each inter-assay comparison, we calculated the concordance by comparing the number of concordant samples with the number of samples that tested positive on at least one assay. Results Sixteen studies fulfilled inclusion criteria, comparing nine assays to HC2, and including 392 to 9451 patients each. The calculated concordance varied between 48% and 69% for HC2 and APTIMA, Cobas, Abbott RealTime, Cervista, GP5+/6+, CLART, BD HPV test, Amplicor and Linear Array, i.e. 31%–52% of all positive tests on any pair of compared assays were discordant. Although modest variation in the degree of concordance with HC2 was suggested for particular assays, the numbers of studies per assay were generally low. No pronounced systematic patterns were observed by study (e.g. liquid medium) or population characteristics. Conclusions The ten commercially available assays do not detect the same HPV infections. Even in the most favourable case, the two assays provided discordant test results in 31% of all detected infections.

titleText.ttltext: Capturing Budget Impact Considerations Within Economic Evaluations: A @hit_startSystematic Review@hit_end of Economic Evaluations of Rotavirus @hit_startVaccine@hit_end in Low- and Middle-Income Countries and a Proposed Assessment Framework

organizations: Initiative for Vaccine Research, World Health Organization

paras: Background: In low- and middle-income countries, budget impact is an important criterion for funding new interventions, particularly for large public health investments such as new @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. However, budget impact @hit_startanalyses@hit_end remain less frequently conducted and less well researched than cost-effectiveness @hit_startanalyses@hit_end. Objective: The objective of this study was to fill the gap in research on budget impact @hit_startanalyses@hit_end by assessing (1) the quality of stand-alone budget impact @hit_startanalyses@hit_end, and (2) the feasibility of extending cost-effectiveness @hit_startanalyses@hit_end to capture budget impact. Methods: We developed a budget impact @hit_startanalysis@hit_end checklist and scoring system for budget impact @hit_startanalyses@hit_end, which we then adapted for cost-effectiveness @hit_startanalyses@hit_end, based on current International Society for Pharmacoeconomics and Outcomes Research Task Force recommendations. We applied both budget impact @hit_startanalysis@hit_end and cost-effectiveness @hit_startanalysis@hit_end checklists and scoring systems to examine the extent to which existing economic evaluations provide sufficient evidence about budget impact to enable decision making. We used rotavirus @hit_startvaccination@hit_end as an illustrative case in which low- and middle-income countries uptake has been limited despite demonstrated cost effectiveness. A @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end was conducted to identify economic evaluations of rotavirus @hit_startvaccine@hit_end in low- and middle-income countries published between January 2000 and February 2017. We critically appraised the quality of budget impact @hit_startanalyses@hit_end, and assessed the extension of cost-effectiveness @hit_startanalyses@hit_end to provide useful budget impact information. Results: Six budget impact @hit_startanalyses@hit_end and 60 cost-effectiveness @hit_startanalyses@hit_end were identified. Budget impact @hit_startanalyses@hit_end adhered to most International Society for Pharmacoeconomics and Outcomes Research recommendations, with key exceptions being provision of undiscounted financial streams for each budget period and model validation. Most cost-effectiveness @hit_startanalyses@hit_end could not be extended to provide useful budget impact information; cost-effectiveness @hit_startanalyses@hit_end also rarely presented undiscounted annual costs, or estimated financial streams during the first years of programme scale-up. Conclusions: Cost-effectiveness @hit_startanalyses@hit_end vastly outnumber budget impact @hit_startanalyses@hit_end of rotavirus @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, despite both being critical for policy decision making. Straightforward changes to the presentation of cost-effectiveness @hit_startanalyses@hit_end results could facilitate their adaptation into budget impact @hit_startanalyses@hit_end.

titleText.ttltext: Incidence rate of breakthrough varicella observed in healthy children after 1 or 2 doses of varicella @hit_startvaccine@hit_end: Results from a @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics School of Public Health, Sichuan University

paras: Background Although extensive varicella @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage has been reported in many countries, breakthrough varicella (BV) still occurs in healthy children. We performed a @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end to understand whether 2 varicella @hit_startvaccine@hit_end doses are needed in children and, if so, to determine the best time to @hit_startvaccinate@hit_end. Methods The BV incidence rates after 1 or 2 doses of varicella @hit_startvaccine@hit_end were pooled using random effects, and 95% confidence intervals (CI) were used to estimate the risk factors after @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. Results A total of 27 original articles were included in this @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end. The pooled average BV incidence rate in children @hit_startvaccinated@hit_end with 1 dose was 8.5 cases per 1,000 person years (PY) (95% confidence interval [CI], 5.3-13.7; random effects model) and 2.2 cases per 1,000 PY (95% CI, 0.5-9.3; random effects model) in children @hit_startvaccinated@hit_end with 2 doses. The pooled trend of the annual BV incidence rate from the first to eighth year fluctuated, with a peak annual incidence rate of 35.3 cases per 1,000 population in the fourth year. The @hit_startmeta@hit_end-regression showed that design type, type of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, and their interaction accounted for approximately 71.74% of the heterogeneity in the average BV incidence rate after 1 @hit_startvaccine@hit_end dose. Conclusions Two doses of varicella @hit_startvaccine@hit_end are more effective than a single dose, and 3-4 years between the first and second @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end may achieve higher efficacy.

titleText.ttltext: Registry-based randomized controlled trials merged the strength of randomized controlled trails and observational studies and give rise to more pragmatic trials

organizations: Institute for Research in Operative Medicine, Chair of Surgical Research, Faculty of Health, School of Medicine, Witten/Herdecke University

paras: Objectives The objective of this study was to @hit_startanalyze@hit_end the features of registry-based randomized trials (rRCTs). Study Design and Setting We systematically searched @hit_startPubMed@hit_end for rRCTs. Study selection was performed independently by two reviewers. We extracted all data in standardized tables and prepared descriptive summary statistics. Results The search resulted in 1,202 hits. We included 71 rRCTs. Most rRCTs were from Denmark and Sweden. Chronic conditions were considered in 82.2%. A preventive intervention was examined in 45.1%. The median of included patients was 2,000 (range: 69–246,079). Definition of the study population was mostly broad. Study procedures were regularly little standardized. The number of included and @hit_startanalyzed@hit_end patients was the same in 82.1%. In half of the rRCTs, more than one registry was utilized. Various linkage techniques were used. In median, two outcomes were collected from the registry/ies. The median follow-up of the rRCTs was 5.3 years (range: 6 weeks to 27 years). Information on quality of registry data was reported in 11.3%. Conclusion rRCTs can provide valid (randomization, low lost-to-follow-up rates, generalizable) patient important long-term comparative-effectiveness data for relative little effort. Researchers planning an RCT should always check whether existing registries can be used for data collection. Reporting on data quality must be improved for use in evidence synthesis.
